Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Dating mineralization in a Carlin-type gold deposit: A test of the Fe-oxide (U-Th)/He chronometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Carlin-type gold deposits (CTGDs) of northern Nevada are the source of most of the gold production in the United States and are thus of major economic importance; however, their geologic origin is uncertain. Various models for deposit formation relate the gold mineralization to different geologic events which likely occurred at different times, including magmatic activity, or circulation of groundwater-derived fluids through deeper gold-bearing units in the crust. Because of the lack of easily dateable minerals in CTGDs, it has historically been challenging to determine when gold mineralization occurred. The result is that effective exploration is hampered by the lack of knowledge about how and when these deposits formed. In this study, a new method of dating these deposits will be refined and tested. If the ages of CTGD formation could be more definitively known, gold mineralization could be correlated to broader geologic processes that were occurring at the same time. This knowledge would enable scientists and explorers to more easily discover new deposits.

Available geochronological data suggest that Carlin-type mineralization broadly overlapped in space and time with the southwest sweep of Eocene magmatism through Nevada. Geo- and thermochronologic datasets are critical to identify direct evidence that magmatism and ore formation overlapped at individual deposits. Indeed, new chronometric tools could greatly expand knowledge of the genetic processes that lead to CTGD formation. No straightforward method currently exists to date CTDG mineralization. Recent studies have explored the use of the (U-Th)/He chronometer for Fe-oxides, but this chronometer has not been systematically tested in ore deposits. The proposed research has two major goals: to test feasibility of the Fe-oxide (U-Th)/He chronometer to date hydrothermal fluid flow, and to use this method to determine the age of hydrothermal activity in a CTGD in Nevada.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project's goals were to test the feasibility of new tools for mineral exploration in the Carlin Trend Gold Deposits (CTGD) of northern Nevada. Gold is critical to the functioning of society as nearly every piece of electronic equipment contains a small amount of gold. Because nearly 75% of US gold production comes from CTGD in northern Nevada (Nevada Mining Association, 2014), this industry plays a large role in economic development in rural Nevada. The social and environmental impacts of mining are substantial and complex, highlighting the need for good science to support ore deposit research and mineral exploration: the more we know about how these deposits formed, the more choice we have in where and how to mine.

A key aspect of this work centered around finding the timing of mineralization. If we know when the mineralization occurred, then we can better test various models of howthe mineralization occurred. Moreover, the ability to constrain the timing of mineralization could be used as a predictive tool in the future. That is, if we find indicators that a deposit is the same age as an established CTGD, then it may be a prospect for future development. Here, we explored the use of a new type of dating: iron-oxide, uranium-thorium/helium (or (U-Th)/He) dating. In this technique, the amounts of U and Th (the parent) in an Fe-oxide are compared to the amount of He (the daughter) in the same grain to obtain an age. Dates were collected from Fe-oxide (e.g. hematite) grains in mineral assemblages referred to as jasperoids (aggregates of Fe-oxide and quartz mineral phases) that often occur in coincidence with CTGDs. The hypotheses we tested encompassed whether a) the Fe-oxide dates we obtain from jasperoid samples yield reproducible and geologically significant ages, and b) these ages are consistent with an age of 40 million years old (Ma) obtained from other independent methods that suggests a timing for formation of CTGD. Because this grant was an EAGER, much of the work was exploratory and served as a proof-of-concept. 

Our results are promising and will be published in several peer-reviewed articles within the coming year. We found samples that gave consistent Fe-oxide (U-Th)/He ages, although many of them were substantially younger than the expected age of 40 Ma. The majority of our ages were in the 1-5 Ma range. Intriguing, this age overlaps with other observations in the western U.S. from paleoclimate (i.e. “ancient” climate) and paleo-ground water records that suggest a shift to a wetter climate at this time period. That is, we may have dated the timing of alteration associated with water-rock interaction as a consequence of our study area being exposed to the near-surface water table. Although this result was slightly unexpected, knowledge of the onset of late-stage, ground water alteration in these deposits is still valuable information for describing the full history of mineralization at these sites. Furthermore, our results contribute to the growing body of evidence that Fe-oxide (U-Th)/He dating may be a powerful technique for understanding the timing of ancient water-rock interactions on Earth and other planets.
